prior_works.title: Deep Learning with Differential Privacy
prior_works.authors: Martin Abadi, Andy Chu, Ian Goodfellow, H. Brendan McMahan, Ilya Mironov, Kunal Talwar, Li Zhang
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper established DP-SGD—the mechanism whose implementations the ICML 2024 work scrutinizes—and popularized Poisson subsampling-based privacy accounting that the new paper shows can diverge from shuffling-based practice.

prior_works.title: Rényi Differential Privacy
prior_works.relationship_sentence: RDP underpins modern, numerically tight privacy accountants used to analyze Poisson-subsampled DP-SGD, providing the baseline the ICML 2024 paper contrasts against shuffling-based implementations.

prior_works.title: Subsampled Rényi Differential Privacy and Analytical Moments Accountant
prior_works.authors: Yu-Xiang Wang, Borja Balle, Shiva Prasad Kasiviswanathan
prior_works.role: Tight analysis of Poisson subsampling and practical accountant
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work gives tight RDP bounds and the analytical moments accountant for the subsampled Gaussian mechanism, directly enabling the common (Poisson-based) practice whose mismatch with shuffling-based DP-SGD the new paper quantifies.

prior_works.title: Privacy Amplification by Subsampling: Tight Analyses via Couplings
prior_works.role: Amplification results for different subsampling schemes
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By distinguishing privacy amplification under Poisson vs. sampling-without-replacement, this paper provides the theoretical lens the ICML 2024 work leverages to argue that the sampling rule materially affects DP-SGD’s guarantees.

prior_works.title: Privacy Amplification by Iteration
prior_works.authors: Vitaly Feldman, Ilya Mironov, Kunal Talwar, Abhradeep Guha Thakurta
prior_works.role: Iterative analysis relevant to without-replacement DP-SGD
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work offers tools to analyze iterative noisy updates (as in DP-SGD with shuffled minibatches), informing the ICML 2024 paper’s focus on how shuffling-based training departs from Poisson-subsampled analyses.

prior_works.title: Gaussian Differential Privacy
prior_works.authors: Jinshuo Dong, Aaron Roth, Weijie J. Su
prior_works.role: Unified metric and conversions used in accountants
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GDP provides a unifying lens and accurate conversions between privacy notions that many accountants use; the ICML 2024 work’s comparison of guarantees implicitly relies on these standardized accounting foundations.

synthesis_narrative:
The ICML 2024 paper targets a widely overlooked mismatch: practitioners typically implement DP-SGD with shuffled, fixed-size minibatches (sampling without replacement) yet analyze privacy using Poisson-subsampled accountants. The intellectual pathway to this finding begins with Abadi et al. (2016), which introduced DP-SGD and the moments accountant, setting the canonical mechanism and practice of subsampling-based analysis. Mironov’s Rényi Differential Privacy (2017) then provided a powerful composition framework that enabled tight, scalable accounting. Building on RDP, Wang, Balle, and Kasiviswanathan (2019) delivered tight bounds for the subsampled Gaussian mechanism and the analytical moments accountant, cementing Poisson subsampling as the default analysis path and powering modern open-source accountants.

However, the training-time reality often uses shuffled, without-replacement minibatching. Balle and Wang (2018) gave tight amplification results that separate Poisson and without-replacement sampling, highlighting that the sampling rule fundamentally changes privacy. Feldman et al. (2018) further developed privacy amplification by iteration, offering tools to reason about iterative procedures like DP-SGD under shuffling. Finally, Dong, Roth, and Su (2019) introduced Gaussian Differential Privacy, a unifying metric that normalizes comparisons across analyses.

Together, these works enabled precise Poisson-based accounting while revealing conceptual gaps for shuffling-based implementations. The ICML 2024 paper leverages this foundation to formalize DP-SGD as post-processing of adaptive batch linear queries and to demonstrate that shuffling and Poisson subsampling can yield substantially different privacy guarantees—showing that prevalent practice can materially misestimate privacy.
